Blastocystis hominis is a single-celled eukaryotic microorganism that is commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract of humans and a wide range of other animals. It is considered a protist, belonging to the Stramenopila group, which includes various types of algae and water molds.

The life cycle of Blastocystis hominis involves several stages, including the vacuolar, granular, and amoeboid forms. The vacuolar form is the most commonly observed and is characterized by a central vacuole surrounded by a thin cytoplasmic layer. This stage is believed to be the predominant form found in the host's intestine.

Blastocystis hominis is known to be one of the most common eukaryotic microorganisms found in the human gut, with prevalence rates ranging from 0.5% to 60% in different populations. While the pathogenicity of Blastocystis hominis is still a subject of debate, it has been associated with various gastrointestinal symptoms, such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and bloating, in some individuals.

The transmission of Blastocystis hominis is primarily through the ingestion of contaminated food or water, and it can be spread through person-to-person contact as well. The treatment of Blastocystis hominis infections often involves the use of antiprotozoal medications, although the effectiveness of these treatments is still being investigated.
